question: A potential at a point A is 3 V and that at another point B is 5V. What is the work done in carrying a charge of 5 mC from B to A?
explanation: Work done <katex>$W = q(V_{final} - V_{initial}) = q(V_A - V_B)$</katex>
<katex>$W = -10 \times 10^{-3} = -0.01$</katex> J. (Wait, the options and solution in source indicate 0.04J/0.01J mismatch. Let's re-read source solution).
Source solution calculation: <katex>$5 \times 10^{-3} (-3, -5) = -8 \times 5...$</katex> This seems like a calculation error in source. Let's check source values again. 3V and 5V. 5mC.
Source says: <katex>$5 \times 10^{-3} (V_A - V_B) = 5 \times 10^{-3} (3 - 11?)$</katex> No, text says 3V and 5V clearly.

Source Solution: <katex>$= 5 \times 10^{-3} (-8)$</katex> ... implies voltage diff is -8? Maybe -3V and 5V? Or 3V and 11V? The text says 3V and 5V. But result is -0.04J. <katex>-0.04 / 5e-3 = -8</katex>. So potential difference used was -8V. This implies <katex>V_A - V_B = -8</katex>. If <katex>V_B = 5</katex>, <katex>V_A = -3</katex>.
